body: Hi! Is you're interested in Intel HW optimizations, we have a proposal: https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/pull/1686

Hey @Seyij thanks for this! Indeed we moved to TF2, but also support still running TF1 as well; it might be a "simple" fix in this way. If you want to document what the errors you face, I can try to help guide ways!

> Hi! Is you're interested in Intel HW optimizations, we have a proposal: #1686
Thank you for this, I'm not familiar with this, so I'll have a look.

> Hey @Seyij thanks for this! Indeed we moved to TF2, but also support still running TF1 as well; it might be a "simple" fix in this way. If you want to document what the errors you face, I can try to help guide ways!
Sure thing, I'll try the method again and work through a standard Deeplabcut example. I'll post specific details here of my findings.

Hello, I'll try and summarise some of my findings from trying to get it to work here.

**Summary**

A key part of getting tensorflow-directml to work is just to get it to recognise the GPU. Tested on older versions of tensorflow via:
```python
import tensorflow as tf
sess = tf.Session(config=tf.ConfigProto(log_device_placement=True))
```
To get this to work, I changed the order of installation so that tensorflow-directml dependencies supersede the deeplabcut one. This allowed my integrated and dedicated GPU to be recognised.

Unfortunately when I tried to import deeplabcut I got an extremely large error traceback that ended in ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'numpy.typing'. I assume this is because tensorflow-directml 1.15.5needs a version of numpy that doesn't have numpy.typing. I'll do more tests to see this can be solved with a numpy version that works with both deeplabcut and tensorflow 1.15.5. Below I have the error report, any advice will be appreciated!

---

```python

```

**Some details of other tests**

I set up an environment as follows:
```shell
conda create -n dlc_dml python=3.7
conda activate dlc_dml
pip install tensorflow-directml
pip install "deeplabcut[gui]"
```
And this causes incopatible tensorflow versions to be installed as pip says deeeplabcut needs tensorflow >2, but the tensorflow and tensorflow-directml need to be the same version.
```shell
##This is a subset of package details, as a output from conda list
tensorflow                2.8.0                    pypi_0    pypi
tensorflow-directml       1.15.5                   pypi_0    pypi
tensorflow-estimator      1.15.1                   pypi_0    pypi
```
After this I installed tensorflow 1.15.5 and received this informative error:
```shell
pip install tensorflow==1.15.5
ERROR: pip's dependency resolver does not currently take into account all the packages that are installed. This behaviour is the source of the following dependency conflicts.
imageio 2.16.0 requires numpy>=1.20.0, but you have numpy 1.18.5 which is incompatible.
deeplabcut 2.2.0.6 requires tensorflow>=2.0, but you have tensorflow 1.15.5 which is incompatible.
Successfully installed numpy-1.18.5 tensorboard-1.15.0 tensorflow-1.15.5
```
After this the GPU still was not recognised. I conducted a variety of other tests that I can report on if the details and error reports will be helpful.

Hello, @Seyij!

I also tried deeplabcut with tensorflow-directml about a year ago and I reported it in [image.sc](http://image.sc/) forum. 
That report is bit old version, but it may be helpful for you!
https://forum.image.sc/t/fyi-deeplabcut-worked-on-radeon-gpu-rtx3080-using-tensorflow-directml/47700

On my most recent experience, I could run deeplabcut on tensorflow-directml at 2021/6, and that specifications like below:

CPU: Ryzen5 5600X
GPU: Radeon 6900XT
python ver: 3.7
dlc ver: 2.2rc2
tf-dML ver: tensorflow_directml-1.15.5.dev210429

Hi @bobfromjapan Thanks very much for this, exactly what I need! This should help me figure out the rest!

Hello! I found an instruction set that works, tested on a few deeplabcut models and GPU acceleration is working great!

```shell
conda create --name dlc_dml python=3.7
conda activate dlc_dml
#specific version just in case something changes later
pip install deeplabcut[gui]==2.2.0.6
pip install tensorflow-directml==1.15.5
pip install pip install imageio==2.9.0
```
Since now there is a set of version numbers this should not break unless pip itself has a significant change in the future. 
I have a pip requirements file that has the resultant configuration. I also have a conda environment file but I was unable to upload that to this issue comment.
[tf_dml_pip.txt](https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/files/8196775/tf_dml_pip.txt)

Thanks all for your help so far!
In terms of making this useful for other people, would providing the command line install instructions as above be more helpful, or providing a conda environment, or both?

Hey @Seyij want to write a cookbook/docs update entry for this? Would be awesome!

(1) edit this to add new info on hardware, i.e. if you have X, then you just need to do Y" 👍  https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/blob/master/docs/recipes/TechHardware.md

(2) If you want to also add a section here, on a "how to": https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/blob/master/docs/recipes/installTips.md
Yes thanks I'd be happy to do that!

issue.title: added tf-directml install tip to docs

repository.name: DeepLabCut
repository.description: Official implementation of DeepLabCut: Markerless pose estimation of user-defined features with deep learning for all animals incl. humans

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body: As dicussed in #1687 , I have added installation instructions in install tips for Deeplabcut that allow GPU acceleration on AMD, Intel and Nvidia GPUs.

issue.title: Deeplabcut-Live with AMD GPU

repository.name: DeepLabCut-live
repository.description: SDK for running DeepLabCut on a live video stream

issue.body:
Hi Deeplabcut-Live developer
I have ran Deeplabcut-live smoothly on NVIDIA GPU and now I have a computer setup that uses AMD GPU.
According to the classic Deeplabcut installation guidance <https://deeplabcut.github.io/DeepLabCut/docs/recipes/installTips.html>
I should be able to use AMD GPU by installing tensorflow-directml in the conda environment?!
I have not seen a benchmark report about AMD GPU so I am curious if anyone has experience about this.
Best Regards

Chi-Yu
